__data__.text: In December 1982, the HAMC (Hells Angels Motorcycle Club) established chapters in Anchorage and Fairbanks, Alaska, after merging with the Brothers MC. The Brothers MC had originated in 1967 and had formed an association with the Hells Angels in California's San Francisco Bay Area by 1977. This summary conveys the same concept as the original text, indicating when and where the HAMC established chapters in Alaska, as well as the background of the Brothers MC.

In December 1982, the Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC) established chapters in Anchorage and Fairbanks, Alaska, following a merger with the Brothers MC, which had originated in 1967 and had links to the HAMC in California's San Francisco Bay Area by 1977. During a ceremony in California, the Brothers MC "patched over" to the HAMC, with members from the Fairbanks chapter present. The HAMC, including its Alaskan chapters, has been involved in methamphetamine trafficking, as revealed in Operation CACUS.

In 1985, Anthony John Tait, a member serving as the sergeant-at-arms of the Anchorage Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC) chapter, decided to cooperate with the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) by becoming a paid informant, following the HAMC's expansion in Alaska through a merger with the Brothers MC in 1982 and their involvement in methamphetamine trafficking, as exposed in Operation CACUS.

In 1985, the sergeant-at-arms of the Anchorage Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC) chapter, Anthony John Tait, became a paid FBI informant, sharing comprehensive data about the club's structure and illegal activities, including drug and explosive trafficking, during a two-year period. This came after the HAMC's expansion in Alaska through a merger with the Brothers MC in 1982 and the revelation of their involvement in methamphetamine trafficking in Operation CACUS.

From 1985 to 1987, Anthony John Tait, the sergeant-at-arms of the Anchorage Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC) chapter, served as an FBI informant, collaborating closely with the government. Tait's role involved traveling across the country at their expense to confer with numerous Hells Angels members. In an effort to gather evidence, he covertly recorded certain conversations by wearing a wire during these meetings. This clandestine operation took place after the HAMC's expansion in Alaska through a merger with the Brothers MC in 1982 and the subsequent discovery of their illicit involvement in methamphetamine and explosive trafficking during Operation CACUS.

During the investigation from 1985 to 1987, the FBI informant and undercover agents bought approximately $1.6 million worth of cocaine and methamphetamine, over twenty pounds of explosives, three automatic weapons, and two silencers from the Hells Angels Motorcycle Club's Anchorage chapter. This was done to collect evidence following the HAMC's involvement in methamphetamine and explosive trafficking after their expansion in Alaska in 1982.

In the investigation from 1985 to 1987, the FBI made purchases of illegal substances and weapons from the Anchorage chapter of the Hells Angels Motorcycle Club to gather evidence of their involvement in methamphetamine and explosive trafficking. This led to the OCDETF Operation CACUS, which resulted in the arrest of 38 HAMC members in Alaska and four other states on charges related to narcotics, weapons, explosives, and conspiracy on November 10, 1987.

In the investigation from 1985 to 1987, the FBI arrested Edward Floyd Hubert, the president of the Anchorage Hells Angels Motorcycle Club chapter, and Dennis E. Pailing, the president of the Fairbanks chapter, along with 12 other individuals. The arrests occurred during raids at residences in Anchorage and a compound in Fairbanks, conducted by FBI and ATF agents. The raids and subsequent arrests were part of the OCDETF Operation CACUS, which targeted the Hells Angels' involvement in methamphetamine and explosive trafficking, leading to the arrest of 38 club members in Alaska and four other states.

The FBI and ATF raids in Anchorage and Fairbanks in 1985-1987, as part of Operation CACUS, resulted in the arrest of Hells Angels leaders Edward Floyd Hubert and Dennis E. Pailing, along with 12 others. These arrests were due to the group's involvement in methamphetamine and explosive trafficking. Later, 10 Hells Angels members from California and Alaska, including Hubert and Pailing, were extradited to Kentucky to face charges of conspiring to transport firearms and explosives across state lines with the intent to murder Outlaws members in retaliation for John Cleave Webb's death.

The former Anchorage Hells Angels president, known as John Cleave Webb, was tragically killed by two Outlaws members in a Jefferson County, Kentucky saloon in August 1986. This incident was a significant factor that led to the FBI and ATF raids in Alaska and the subsequent arrests of Hells Angels leaders, including Edward Floyd Hubert and Dennis E. Pailing, for their involvement in methamphetamine and explosive trafficking, as well as a conspiracy to transport firearms and explosives across state lines to retaliate against the Outlaws.

In October 1988, Anchorage Hells Angels members Hubert, Hagel, and Protzman were found guilty of misdemeanor charges for utilizing a government intelligence manual for their own purposes. Meanwhile, Pailing and four other Alaskan Angels were acquitted. This conviction took place over two years after the 1986 killing of the Anchorage Hells Angels president, John Cleave Webb, by Outlaws members, which resulted in FBI and ATF raids and arrests of Hells Angels leaders for various criminal activities.

After the 1986 killing of the Anchorage Hells Angels president, Webb, and the subsequent FBI/ATF raids and arrests, some members of the Alaska and California chapters faced convictions on separate state drug and firearm charges. This occurred both before and after the federal trial related to the misdemeanor charges. Additionally, there were allegations of a $1 million bounty placed on Tait's life by the Hells Angels, and a federal racketeering case was also in the picture.

In December 2003, four members of the Alaska Hells Angels, specifically Montgomery David Elliott, Michael Hurn, Dale Leedom, and William Spearman, were apprehended by ATF agents during raids in Anchorage and Two Rivers on charges of federal racketeering and firearm offenses. This occurred in the context of the ongoing legal issues faced by some Hells Angels members from the Alaska and California chapters, who had previously been convicted on separate state drug and firearm charges both before and after a federal trial related to misdemeanor offenses. In 1996, the Dirty Dozen motorcycle club in Arizona decided to join the Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC), and they officially became a part of the HAMC during a gathering in Oakland, California, in October 1997. In 1997, the Dirty Dozen motorcycle club in Arizona became a part of the Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC), leading to the creation of six HAMC chapters in Arizona, including ones in Phoenix, Mesa, Tucson, Cave Creek, Flagstaff, and a nomads chapter. In 2001, the leaders of the Arizona nomads chapter of the Hells Angels Motorcycle Club, Greg "Snake" Surdukan and Chris "Porker" Baucum, who were previously from the Dirty Dozen motorcycle club, were involved in the illegal methamphetamine trafficking activity that the HAMC was engaged in after the merger with the Dirty Dozen in 1997, which led to the establishment of HAMC chapters in Arizona.

In 2001, the leaders of the Arizona Hells Angels Motorcycle Club, Greg "Snake" Surdukan and Chris "Porker" Baucum, who had joined after the club's merger with the Dirty Dozen in 1997, were apprehended and accused of illicit drug trafficking. This charge came as a result of the Drug Enforcement Administration discovering a global drug operation that involved importing methamphetamine into the United States from South Africa.

In 1999, Hells Angels members from South Africa and Arizona, including Surdukan and Baucum, were implicated in a drug smuggling operation that involved mailing methamphetamine, concealed in stuffed toys, from South Africa to Flagstaff, and then distributing it to other states across the U.S.

In 2002, Hells Angels members Surdukan and Baucum, previously linked to a South African-Arizona drug smuggling case using stuffed toys, admitted to trafficking charges. In 2001, the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms (ATF) launched an undercover operation, known as Operation Black Biscuit, targeting the Arizona Hells Angels after involving a member from the Tijuana-based Solo Angeles, Rudolph "Rudy" Kramer. In 2001, Operation Black Biscuit involved the ATF enlisting a Solo Angeles member named Rudy Kramer to infiltrate other gangs, resulting in a 21-month undercover operation conducted by ATF agents, technicians, and informants within the club. In July 2002, Rudy Kramer, an undercover ATF informant, introduced ATF agents, posing as Solo Angeles bikers, to Hells Angels leaders in Arizona, following a meeting with Robert "Bad Bob" Johnston Jr., the head of the Mesa chapter. In an attempt to maintain their credibility among the Hells Angels in Arizona, undercover ATF agent Jay Dobyns informed them in June 2003 that he and another Solo Angeles biker were planning a trip to Sonora to assassinate Mongols members. To uphold their trustworthiness with the Hells Angels in Arizona, the ATF, through undercover agent Jay Dobyns, revealed in June 2003 a fictional plan of killing a Mongols member in Sonora. In order to maintain their reliability with the Hells Angels in Arizona, the ATF, using undercover agent Jay Dobyns, devised a phony plot in June 2003 to murder a Mongols member in Sonora. The ATF considered Operation Black Biscuit a success, but due to internal discord and conflicting government opinions, the 16 defendants avoided conviction for racketeering and murder charges. After cooperating with the ATF as an informant for over a year, Kramer, who had infiltrated the Skull Valley Hells Angels, agreed to a plea deal for Cynthia Garcia's murder, receiving a sentence of five years' probation. He was eventually found in Buenos Aires, Argentina, on February 3, 2011, by the USMS, DSS, and Interpol, and was listed as one of the USMS's 15 Most Wanted Fugitives.

Kramer, a fugitive since 2007, was discovered in Argentina and listed among the USMS's top 15 wanted. After losing all appeals, he was extradited to Arizona in 2018. Augustiniak admitted to second-degree murder in 2011 and received a 23.5-year sentence in March 2012.
